Posts.Content: As a supervisor, the people under you are probably more understanding than your boss. If you hadn't been feeling so bad you would not have cried and also would have not been chastised by him (?) to cause you to cry. Don't be intimidated. I would change the primary care doctor - I take Prozac and swear it made the whole ordeal easier. If people are honest I think they will admit that they are more tired than before all the treatments. Also think the tamoxifen has some effect on energy too. I have aches all over - fortunately not all at the same time but everyday - however retirement helps me a lot too. Don't resign yet. And give your boss some educational information - obviously you were doing all right to get the promotion. Good Luck - keep us informed when you feel up to it. Jean
Posts.Title: help--need some advice

Posts.Content: Alicia, I haven't gone thru this but since I see no answer to you as of this moment, I am surprised that your doctors did not tell you the only option for this as Hodgins' patients survive and live a long time now is mastectomy - no more radiation to the chest as you had it with the first disease. From what I've read, the results are very good as it is usually a local disease due to the radiation. Good Luck! Jean You might click into google.com with"breast cancer after hodgkins"
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer after Hodgkin's?

Posts.Content: If true, vitamin K helps the blood clot and since Tamoxifen has a small tendency to produce blood clots, that would be the last combination you would need. Any greens will give you vitamon K - how about a salad?
Posts.Title: wheat grass

Posts.Content: Tara, I could have found all the medical information I wanted from websites, but this forum - having people in the same boat to talk to - was an added dividend. I could not have received encouragement as here from an inanimate website. I have made some good friends here on the site and we write directly. I feel a kinship with all of you here. When I don't see a person anymore I wonder how she is doing. and I mourn for those who leave us not because of choice. CSN is a community unlike an informational website which is invaluable - more from the medical side. Here we get emotional support - lifting of our spirits - sympathy when we need it - all human elements so important at this time in our lives. Hope this helps. good Luck on your presentation. Jean
Posts.Title: Another Conference to attend.

Posts.Content: WHOOPS! Marie, thank you! You are soooo right about celebrex. The name is a close one - maybe celexa? -it's only been around a few years. Celebrex and Vioxx for pain :-) I did not like Zoloft - made me feel rather groggy and eventually gave me diarrhea which I read if you can get thru that, it stops. Forget it, I quit it. Also did not like Paxil for the same reason but have liked Prozac a lot. Do you like Celebrex for pain. I've read several places they think it may have anti-cancer qualities. If so would be a good pain pill for all of us. Jean
Posts.Title: St. John's Wort and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: I'll be willing to bet (if I were a betting woman) that a cancer center would do a lumpectomy and follow it with tamoxifen if the tumor is estrogen positive which they usually are in post menopausal women. *Let us know what really happens.* I would not have MY mother taking radiation at 93 nor myself - think of how delicate her skin must be! Wishing your Mom smooth sailing - think a long time about the radiation and get a second opinion because radiation does not follow immediately. Jean
Posts.Title: 93 year old with breast cancer

Posts.Content: SSRI's are the newer anti-depressants like zoloft, paxil, prozac, celebrex, etc.
Posts.Title: St. John's Wort and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Dear Wendy, >>You can all do it-----its a piece of cake!!! (Yum.....cake!! Maybe I'll go and have some!!) You are amazing!! How you can write such a matter-of-fact and coherent letter to us on such a weighty subject is, as I've already said, amazing. You'll have lots of positive thoughts and prayers from many of us here who will be praying for success and future health for you. Courage and love and prayers to you from Jean
Posts.Title: Quick Update

Posts.Content: CFM is Cyclophosphamide(Cytoxan), Fluorouracil (not sure of the spelling but it's called 5-FU), and methotrexate. This combo was used before AC and is still used. The doctoer at the south pole got that when she ret'd. Usually AC (Adriamycin & Cytoxan) are used now, but they usually give the MUGA test to your heart first and if that indicates your heart is not strong enough, then CFM - usually called CMF. Sometimes CAF is given in place of just AC. Xeloda is an oral pill given for metastatic cancer and converts in the body to 5-FU. How do I know this - the first onco I had explained all the possible combinations of treatments. Jean
Posts.Title: a nubie's question

Posts.Content: Hi Brenda, I don't think we get chemobrain. I think it is the result of stress and too much on one's mind = overload. When I was away for the month's vacation and it was very important to keep track of lots because I was alone, I never misplaced anything - never forgot anything I had to do. I think concentration is the big thing. However 'they' say as one gets older, a person can't multi-task as when younger. Just my thoughts for a friday evening!! :-) Hugs, Jean
Posts.Title: chemobrain

Posts.Content: Hi Susan, Do I remember correctly? You had a LONG drive for radiation - four hours? If I have the right person :-) I see you must have kept on schedule - good for you! Jean
Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Back awhile when I was researching xeloda for someone else, I found information on a reliable site that xeloda was just as effective - if it was working - at a lower dose if the side effects got too bad. So apparently better to take less than to stop -you might want to ask your doctor about this. Hugs to all of you in this thread. Despite the serious subject, you all show a lot of courage and a great sense of humor! Jean
Posts.Title: Now on Zeloda

Posts.Content: You were told the standard procedure to eat mostly cooked foods when your white count is low. I first read this on the internet with first diagnosis, but now three years later, it is promoted more widely. Salads can be unsafe and raw fruit - I now skip grapes etc. and all imported items. I bake apples and eat cooked or canned - not too hard to do.
Posts.Title: raw food

Posts.Content: Hi Emmi, I thought I was a well-informed person on health matters, but I found after getting cancer that I had been quite ignorant!! Used to think if I would have cancer, get rid of BOTH breasts and go back on the Premarin and on with life. Boy, chemo never entered my mind ! I remember when I heard one node positive - still for a few minutes did not realize that chemo was in MY future too. What I just said helps me deal with people who had no idea what it was like. It helps me forgive their ignorance remembering mine. Hope the weather is as beautiful south of Buffalo as it is here. Best wishes, Jean
Posts.Title: Bummer day

Posts.Content: I agreed to be in a clinical trial using either taxol or taxotere for four infusions (every three weeks) or twelve weekly infusions after the four AC. I've had two AC. I have been reading the discussions about taxol but wonder about taxotere. I am thinking of dropping out of the trial if I get taxotere or weekly infusions. Also, I feel like I'm getting a cold so that means my scheduled treatment for the 29th may be off??? I appreciate all the postings and helpful information all you wonderful people are giving to others. Thanks a lot.
Posts.Title: information about taxotere

Posts.Content: >> it's not a matter of 'if' your cancer comes back, it's 'when' your cancer comes back. There's no doubt that State III is serious, but so much for optimism - and thoughtlessness - from the physician's assistant. If you live to age 99, I'll bet you will see a return of cancer. Often the statement has been made that every woman will get breast cancer if she lives long enough. So I'd just go with the hope that everything will be all right for a LONG time - and heck! mets can be treated too. Tell her what you thought of her statement - some people need help in communicating!!! My best wishes, Jean
Posts.Title: New to Site

Posts.Content: To those taking Zometa or Aredia, did you ever have delayed side effects - or am I experiencing something else. First infusion caused a lot of pain for three days after - Fri, Sat, and Sun and then got better than before the infusion. Second treatment was Thursday - some extra pain Friday and then an EASY Saturday and Sunday to my delight - but Monday was worse and Tuesday - woweee! - and today appears to be a repeat of yesterday. Would appreciate your input if you get this treatment - I suppose everythihg can vary from one to the next treatment - of course, I am worried about progression instead of improvement maybe. Sending good wishes to all of you on this forum - and thanks. Jean
Posts.Title: Zometa - delayed side effects(?)

Posts.Content: Depending on the radiation area, many woman never have a regrowth of hair under the affected arm. She can use an electric razor with no problem. Electrolysis in my opinion is overkill. She will find that her underarm is not top priority as she goes through treatment. I wish her good luck. Jean
Posts.Title: Electrolysis question

Posts.Content: Hi All, Spent last week of the 24th May in the hospital getting my heart meds regulated - all NEW stuff. I have now entered the cancer/ heart patient category. Took Herceptin from Dec. 1st weekly including the 17th of May - no heart checks. Had more and more coughing which got worse so when the 24th and the monthly onco's visit came due, I took an overnight bag with me and got a wheelchair at the door of the cancer hospital. Can you believe - I had to do a little persuasion to get him to admit me!!!! Had an echocardiogram that afternoon - ejection fraction of 20. In Feb. 2001 before adriamycin I had a 59 EF. Saw the cardiologist for the first rime on tuesday who gave me the bad news. Said my onco was right on the mark to admit me - this needed inpatient supervision to get regulated. I had to say - well, he was right on the mark after some persuasion from me - damn - how hard the patient must work these days. Anyway I seem to have responded well to Vasotec, Lasix, and Aldactone along with the other 6 meds I still take - sigh........ In June I may be taking another chemo instead of the navelbine. Last of that was the 10th - WBC too low on the 17th. I missed my zometa infusion the 24th but will probably continue that in June. That's my update - I am not a happy camper - but the week in the hospital was a real rest for me who lives alone. Coughing subsided on Wednesday and my biggest job was filling out the meal menu each day. Love to all - keep me in your prayers as I will for all of you. Jean
Posts.Title: herceptin's downside - not pretty

Posts.Content: I had to skip a day for Labor day when I had no choice - radiation was closed for the holiday so my radiation ended on a Monday instead of Friday as the extra day was added on the end. ask them about making up that missed day - would think they intend to do that.
Posts.Title: Skipping a day of radiation

Posts.Content: >>What's the deal? It's always a surprise! Usually straight hair comes in curly - especially with young women _ i'm guessing about the age thing. Mine was silver gray - thick and wavy - grew back straight and the longer on tamoxifen, the thinner it got. Now it is blah gray, and very thin. Of course, the recurrence I have is most on my mind but I MUST ADMIT that sometimes my hair which was so pretty is a real downer! Your hair is probably not in its final state - wait for the next chapter. Jean
Posts.Title: Hair Help...

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy January 2, chemo beginning feb 7 - Friday June22 my third taxol ( had the AC) and never had any scans etc. My doctors at the cancer center I am treated at (part of the NCI) told me early scans are usually negative whether they really are or not because micro cancer cells are too tiny to be picked up. Yet many people get scans anyway - I think fewer scans is the newer way to go - partly to save money, party to reduce needless radiation to the patient, and partly because they are very often not accurate. Ask some questions of www.google.com - I think I will do that too! Good Luck, Jean
Posts.Title: Follow-up care after breast cancer

Posts.Content: http://www.curetoday.com/currentissue/departments/facingchallenge/index.html This is the article in the current CURE magazinr and after reading it I am angry all over again with the surgeon, oncologists, and myself. The last sentence says we must be our own advocate. Damn! that is so annoying and maddening. The specialists should be looking out for our best interests instead of all of us having to do the homework along with being sick, worried, and often unknowing of a lot of things that the god-doctors know but wait for us to holler. I am not a complainer and really had no idea how serious HER2neu is so having had osteoarthritis for years just did not pay close enuf attention to back discomfort. Add the fact that I do not have a pain threshold low like some people who pop a pill at the slightest twinge, I had a grand case of bone mets before *I* hollered - and even the first time I mentioned what seemed like more pain, it was not really listened to. Why am i mad at myself? Well, why did I not even consider bone mets when I had bone pain - why did I think it was the vacuuming or awkward movement mot remembered that was causing it. How DUMB can one get????? Me, who had a medical library of books long before computers were common and drug books with pictures and side effects - the whole scoop. I was so informed but so dumb when this was going on. Forgive me for ranting on - getting it off my chest to whoever will read this. How many of you had bone scans at the time of diagnosis or after treatment was completed? How I wish I were in that group! Appreciate any responses - maybe it does not pay to go to a comprehensive cancer institute affiliated with the NCI as I did. My thoughts and prayers are with all of us in this BIG boat. Jean
Posts.Title: bone scans before pain of bone mets

Posts.Content: Still here - thanks for your kind thoughts. How are YOU doing? I was so shocked that we lost Jane so soon. Good Luck, Jean
Posts.Title: TO JEAN

Posts.Content: Hi Flo, Thanks for sharing your good news that you and hubby are holding up well - continued good luck to you both. Jean
Posts.Title: Kickin butt!!

Posts.Content: It's possible someone might not have the last name. Dave Moore
Posts.Title: Dave's address for sympathy messages

Posts.Content: Dear Pam, You have been through so much and still take the time and make the effort to let us know what's going on and to give others encouragement - you are amazing! I am SO GLAD to hear about the lung tumors and wish you continued good results. Will keep you in my thoughts and prayers. Love, Jean
Posts.Title: Halway results

Posts.Content: Colleen, I've been taking Tamoxifen since the end of Sept. 2001. I think that I was feeling better after chemo and during radiation - then tamoxifen began and I think I've never felt what I call 'good'. I get hot flashes sometimes - mostly in the evening while I'm trying to read or watch TV, but otherwise if I'm not cleaning etc. I feel cooler than I should according to the temperature. I think that is why I could stand France last summer without air conditioning. Sometimes Tamoxifen causes hair thinning in just a small percentage of people. I think I have that and it annoys me more than the cool/hot condition. I think we all hate to complain about these little things which daily wears me down at least and probably many other women. But in the long run, we all say it beats cancer returning. Hoping you will feel better or more comfortable soon. Jean
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen question?
